general: This law makes sure that people who are not allowed to be in certain positions in local government in England cannot run for those positions or hold them. It sets out specific reasons why someone might be disqualified, such as if they have been convicted of a crime or if they owe too much money to the council. This helps ensure that only qualified and trustworthy people can serve in these roles.

series.short: "Local Government Disqualification Act 2022: Sexual Offence-Related Disqualifications for English Local Authorities"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Local Government (Disqualification) Act 2022 disqualifies individuals from being elected or being a member of a local authority in England if they are subject to certain notification requirements or orders related to sexual offences.
* Simplified point 2: The Act adds a new section 81A to the Local Government Act 1972, which outlines the disqualification criteria for sexual offences etc. in England.
* Simplified point 3: The disqualification criteria include any relevant notification requirements or relevant orders related to sexual offences, and the disqualification period starts from the date of the relevant conviction, finding, caution, order, or certification.
* Simplified point 4: The Act also amends the Local Authority (Public Health, Health and Wellbeing Boards and Health Scrutiny) Regulations 2013 to include appointments to Health and Wellbeing Boards, and adds a new paragraph 9A to Schedule 5B of the Local Democracy, Economic Development and Construction Act 2009, which outlines the disqualification criteria for mayors of combined authority areas.
* Simplified point 5: The Act applies to the Mayor of London and London Assembly members, and includes disqualification criteria related to sexual offences etc.
* Simplified point 6: The Act comes into force on the date specified in the commencement of the Local Government (Disqualification) (Coming into Force Date) Order 2022, and the disqualification period starts from the date of the relevant conviction, finding, caution, order, or certification.

series.short: The Local Government (Disqualification) Act 2022: Amending Laws for Changes in the Channel Islands and Isle of Man
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Local Government (Disqualification) Act 2022 allows the Secretary of State to make regulations to amend existing laws to account for changes in the Channel Islands or Isle of Man legislation.
* Simplified point 2: The Act specifies that the regulations made by the Secretary of State must be laid before Parliament and approved by a resolution of each House before they can take effect.
* Simplified point 3: The Act provides for a transitional provision, ensuring that existing notifications and orders are not affected by the amendments made by the Act.
* Simplified point 4: The Act extends only to England and Wales and comes into force two months after it is passed.
* Simplified point 5: The Act may be cited as the Local Government (Disqualification) Act 2022.

series.short: "Disqualification of Local Government Positions in England due to Sexual Offenses"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: Individuals with certain sexual offense-related notifications or orders are disqualified from holding positions in English local authorities.
* Simplified point 2: The Act expands the scope of disqualifying factors for local government positions in England.
* Simplified point 3: The disqualification period begins on the date of the relevant conviction, finding, caution, order, or certification.
* Simplified point 4: Appointments to Health and Wellbeing Boards are included under the disqualification criteria.
* Simplified point 5: The Act affects the Mayor of London and London Assembly members.
* Simplified point 6: The Act's provisions come into force at a future date determined by the Secretary of State.

* If someone has been found guilty of a sexual offense or has received a caution for one, they cannot be elected or appointed to a position in local government in England.
* The law covers people who work on Health and Wellbeing Boards, Mayors of combined authority areas, and other positions in local government.
* The law applies to the Mayor of London and London Assembly members too.
* The law will come into effect two months after it is passed, and it will affect anyone who has been found guilty of a sexual offense or received a caution for one after that date.

So, in short, the Local Government (Disqualification) Act 2022 keeps our communities safe by making sure that people who have been found guilty of sexual offenses or have received cautions for them cannot hold positions in local government.
